name: Spectacle
description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

constellations_primary.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_primary.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

constellations_primary.name: Hell no, we won't go

start.title: Royal tour of Queen Elizabeth II
start.brief_description: In 1954, huge crowds greeted Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip on her Australian tour, all captured by newsreel camera crews who followed the royals around Australia. Footage was also made into the first Australian colour documentary, The Queen in Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Royalty, royalty, royalty
constellations_primary.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

end.title: Melbourne Olympics
end.brief_description: After years of waiting, TV was finally broadcast in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, which was aired by all three Melbourne TV stations and was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America.

constellations_primary.name: No guts, no glory
constellations_primary.description: TV arrived just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The Olympics crystallise ideas of nationalism, athletic heroism, and controversy, all of which have been explored through countless features, documentaries and TV shows.

end.title: Vietnam War
end.brief_description: The Vietnam War is known as ‘the television war’. Images from the front nightly entered people’s living rooms through on-the-ground reportage. As the war progressed, public support waned and by 1969 protests were held, which were also televised.

links.description: TV later played a huge role in uniting the country once again, but this time behind the anti-war effort in response to the ongoing conflict in Vietnam. Footage of the conflict was nightly beamed into households across the country.

end.title: Kokoda Front Line
end.brief_description: This newsreel gave Australians the first glimpse of fighting on the Kokoda Trail and was used as propaganda. Photographer Damien Parer and director Ken G Hall restaged several combat scenes and asked viewers to join the war effort. In 1943, it won Australia’s first Oscar.

constellations_primary.name: The war effort on film
constellations_primary.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

start.title: 'Tank Man' protestor, Tiananmen Square
start.brief_description: ‘An unknown man stared down a column of tanks the morning after the Chinese government massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.

constellations_primary.name: Uncovering the truth
constellations_primary.description: The images of Tank Man during the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989 were captured by photojournalists and shared around the world. The work of journalists has been key to uncovering abuses of power and are rich material for fictional and factual movies and TV.

end.title: September 11
end.brief_description: The world held its breath as two hijacked planes were crashed into the World Trade Center in New York City on 11 September 2001. TV networks around the world bore witness and millions of people saw the historic event unfold in real time.

constellations_primary.name: Post-9/11
constellations_primary.description: The attacks on the World Trader Center in New York City on September 11 2001 were viewed on live television by audiences around the world. The effects of the attack have been explored across various forms of media.
